abstracts.cdata!:
The ratings for the project were as
            follows: the outcome was satisfactory, the sustainability
            was likely, the institutional development impact was
            substantial, the Bank performance was satisfactory, and the
            borrower performance was highly satisfactory. The lessons
            learned indicate that the project addressed issues held in
            high priority by the country, and was therefore backed by
            strong political will. The project was designed as a well
            coordinated package of hardware and software including civil
            works, equipment, drugs, training, Behavioral Change
            Communications (BCC), special campaigns, etc. The project
            management structure was clear with clear lines of
            authority, accountability, and procedures. The members from
            the various ministries and agencies represented in the
            Committee were heavily involved in project preparation, so
            they understood it well and could implement it effectively.
            There was a high level of ownership and transparency from
            the communes upwards. This empowered local people to manage
            the project, although the project design required the Center
            to play a directive role. The Committee and the Project
            Management Unit (PMU) were flexible in their planning,
            needed to respond to the country's rapidly changing
            needs and circumstances between the beginning of project
            preparation in 1993 to the end of the project in 2002.
